definition:
Let us start with two vector bundles $ E $ and $ F $ over a space $ B $
$$E = \Bigl ( \coprod_{\alpha} U_{\alpha} \times \mathbb{R}^{n} \Bigr ) /\{g_{\alpha \beta} \}$$
and
$$F = \Bigl ( \coprod_{\alpha} U_{\alpha} \times \mathbb{R}^{m} \Bigr) /\{h_{\alpha \beta} \}$$

The first objective is to show how to create a bundle called
$ \operatorname{Hom}(E,F) $. There are two different ways to do this.
The first way is to observe that since for vector spaces $ V, W $ that
$ \operatorname{Hom}(V,W) \cong W \otimes V^{\ast} $ (here just meaning
the module of homomorphisms from $ V $ to $ W $) thus if we take the
bundle $ \operatorname{Hom}(E,F) := F \otimes E^{\ast} $ then we have
that since the fibers
$ (F\otimes E^{\ast})_{b} = F_{b} \otimes E^{\ast}_{b} $ we have what we
want.

Another way of looking at the creation of the bundle
$ \operatorname{Hom}(E,F) $ is to look at representations and what we
would ideally like our bundle to look like. If we have that the bundle
that represents $ F $ is given by taking the principle
$ \operatorname{Gl}(m,\mathbb{R}) $ bundle
$$P_{F} = \Bigl( \coprod_{\alpha} U_{\alpha} \times \operatorname{Gl}(m, \mathbb{R}) \Bigl)/\{h_{\alpha \beta} \}$$
and a trivial representation then the bundle afforded by the trivial
representation is simply $ F $. The same thing is true with the bundle
$ E $. We then have that if we look at the structure group of our
proposed new bundle it should be
$ \operatorname{Gl}(m,\mathbb{R}) \times \operatorname{Gl}(n,\mathbb{R}) $.
The fibers of our proposed new bundle definitely should be
$ \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^{n},\mathbb{R}^{m}) $ thus we have that
the representation we are looking for should take something in our
structure group and something in the fiber and give us something new in
the fiber. The proposed representation is
$ \rho(A,B)(U) = A \circ U \circ B^{-1} $. Then looking at the bundle
associated to the representation of $ \rho $ gives us that if
$$P = P_{F} \times P_{E} = \Bigl ( \coprod_{\alpha} U_{\alpha} \times \operatorname{Gl}(m, \mathbb{R}) \times \operatorname{Gl}(n,\mathbb{R}) \Bigr)/\{h_{\alpha \beta} \times g_{\alpha \beta} \}$$
then
$$\operatorname{Hom}(E,F) \equiv P \times_{\rho} \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{R}^{n},\mathbb{R}^{m})$$
we can similarly define
$$\operatorname{Aut}(E) = P_{E} \times_{\rho} \operatorname{Gl}(n,\mathbb{R})$$

The group of sections of $ \operatorname{Aut}(E) $ is called the *gauge
group*. It is a group since we have that if $ (f,f^{\prime}) $ is a
section of $ \operatorname{Aut}(E) $ and $ (\tau,\tau^{\prime}) $ is
also a section of $ \operatorname{Aut}(E) $ then we have a group
operation given by composition: $$\xymatrix{
E \ar[r]^{\tau} \ar[d]^{\pi} & E \ar[r]^{f} \ar[d]^{\pi} & E \ar[d]^{\pi} \\
B \ar[r]^{\tau^{\prime}} & B \ar[r]^{f^{\prime}} & B
}$$ The fact that these bundle maps are isomorphisms of bundles gives
the existence of an inverse. The reason for this is that for each
section $ (f,f^{\prime}) $, $ E_{b} \cong E_{f^{\prime}(b)} $ since
$ f_{b} $ is a vector space isomorphism. Thus we now have that if we
look at the bundle map given by taking
$ \Bigl (f^{-1}, (f^{\prime})^{-1}) \Bigr ) $ (where $ f^{-1} $ means
$ (f_{b})^{-1} $ for each $ b \in B $). Associativity is clear by
composition of functions being associative and the identity map acts as
the identity element.
